Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Humanitarian Logistics Research, Arlington, VA, September 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to host a workshop on Humanitarian Logistics Research. Humanitarian logistics (HL) is involved with the transportation, handling, and distribution of the critical supplies needed by both the population that survives a disaster, and the disaster response itself. Inefficient HL leads to massive human suffering if the population needs are not met, or if critical disaster response functions-such as search and rescue, medical assistance, among other-slow down, or come to a halt, due to the lack of critical supplies. Regrettably the amount of research on this subject of national importance is not commensurate with its importance. Adding to the problem, only a tiny number of researchers in logistics study the realities of HL, the practitioners that have disaster research experience have almost no contact with these researchers, while the social scientists with expertise in disasters have very few interactions with the scholars in HL. These important groups of stakeholders-logisticians, social scientists, and practitioners-tend not to work together to improve the important field of HL. The main objectives of this workshop are to address this issue by: (1) providing a forum for the exchange of ideas and experiences between practitioners and researchers from all relevant disciplines (e.g., social sciences, engineering, logistics) on the subject of HL; (2) helping break barriers and establish links of communication between research communities that typically do not interact with each other; and, (3) defining the key components of a research agenda to addresses basic research needs on HL.

To achieve its objectives, the workshop will be structured around presentations on the topics of "The Realities of Humanitarian Logistics;" "The Social Side of Humanitarian Logistics;" "The Analytics of Humanitarian Logistics;" and "Research Needs on Humanitarian Logistics." These presentations will be followed by breakout discussions to define research agendas on: "The Social Sciences of Humanitarian Logistics" and "The Analytics of Humanitarian Logistics." A plenary discussion will synthesize a comprehensive research agenda. A workshop report will summarize the work done and the key insights of the discussion. The workshop is an extremely cost-effective way to gather worldwide expertise on a subject of national significance, as amply demonstrated by the recent disaster of Super Storm Sandy, and Hurricanes Irene and Lee. The workshop will have a profound impact on the definition of a forward looking research that, by tapping into the expertise of leading scholars from multiple disciplines, addresses the basic research needs of the country to enhance the efficiency of the HL procedures at the core of disaster response procedures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recognizing existing knowledge gaps in Disaster Response Logistics (DRL), the National Science Foundation provided funding to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) to organize a multidisciplinary DRL workshop to establish communication channels between research communities, and to together define a research agenda for the field.

The two-day workshop was held on December 1-2, 2014 at NSF headquarters at Arlington, VA. On Day 1, morning sessions featured researcher and practitioner perspectives on lessons learned and knowledge gaps in DRL. Afternoon sessions identified existing knowledge and research gaps in: (a) material convergence; (b) technology and humanitarian relief; (c) personnel/volunteer convergence; and (d) emerging distribution networks/local distribution. On Day 2, morning sessions examined the complexities of disasters, and explored multidisciplinary collaboration opportunities. Afternoon sessions tackled existing and missing knowledge in: (a) donor behavior/earmarked donations; (b) crisis management and humanitarian contexts; (c) information management and exchange; and (d) supply pipeline planning. 

The workshop underscored the tendency, or temptation, to interpret the logistical challenges faced in DRL from the perspective of commercial logistic (CL) practices. The opinions expressed by DRL practitioners and researchers with experience in large disasters suggest that profound differences exist between CL and DRL. From this perspective, the best way to enhance DRL is to clearly identify commonalities and differences and then undertake a comprehensive research effort that, by building on the commonalities, leads to the development of new paradigms of DRL operations that will effectively reflect, and respond to, its unique features.

The various features of DRL can be broadly classified into three major cluster areas: Complexity, Uncertainty, and Emergence.  In terms of complexity, there is no doubt that the complexity of DRL is heavily influenced, and perhaps determined, by the uncertainty surrounding the operations, and the emergence of social behaviors and practices in post-disaster environments. Managing complexity requires proper attention to both uncertainty and emergence. Managing Complexity, Engaging Uncertainty, and Tapping Emergence provide a solid overarching framework to discuss the research needs identified during the workshop, and to construct comparative analyses between DRL and CL. Managing complexity entails engaging uncertainty, and achieving a better understanding of emergence to channel its tremendous force and resources—personnel, materials, and information—to achieve humanitarian objectives.

In terms of emergence, there are profound differences between CL and DRL. While new technologies and business models can emerge and produce large disruptions to established businesses, these disruptions take place in the span of months, years, and even decades. Significant as these effects may be, they pale in comparison to the speed and force of emergent social behaviors in post-disaster environments. In extreme conditions post-disaster, individuals and social networks of individuals extend, expand, and morph into new forms and conduct tasks that bear little resemblance to those conducted in normal conditions. These rapidly appearing emergent behaviors also fade out quickly as normalcy is established, which further complicates their study. These emergent behaviors add significant complexity to DRL, and their transient nature adds to the difficulty of understanding them.

Discussions from each session resulted in research recommendations in topics ranging from donor behavior to exploiting advances in technology, to the integration of volunteers and emergent groups into relief efforts. By combining social and engineering sciences, approaches can be developed to achieve a balance between planning and flexibility in response efforts. The complexity issues that characterize DRL could be most substantially improved through integration of the multiple agents involved, via efficient and effective communication systems that support decision-making processes.
